Award.AwardTitle: SGER: Dam removal and the response of gravel-bed rivers to sediment pulses
Award.AbstractNarration: This study will investigate sediment transport and channel evolution in gravel-bed rivers<br/>in response to sediment pulses, taking advantage of the field-scale experiment that will be<br/>created by the removal of Milltown Dam on the Clark Fork of the Columbia River, MT. Through<br/>data collection on pre- and post-dam removal channel conditions and on bedload and suspended<br/>load transport out of Milltown reservoir during high flow periods, this research will address<br/>fundamental questions about fluvial processes, sediment transport and deposition, and dam<br/>removal. Several hypotheses will be investigated about how pulses of fine sediment infiltrate<br/>into and affect the mobility of armored river beds, about spatial and temporal patterns of<br/>sediment transport and deposition, and about effective discharges for transporting sediment<br/>pulses. This research will provide an excellent opportunity to evaluate how previous flume<br/>research or field studies of small channels, upon which much of what is known about sediment<br/>transport and related aspects of fluvial processes is based, scale up to larger rivers. The<br/>data collected here will also be evaluated in the context of the implications of geomorphic<br/>responses and sediment geochemistry for habitat and biological processes.<br/>Removal of Milltown Dam, which will begin in spring 2008 and continue the following winter,<br/>is especially notable because (1) it is the largest dam removal to date in the United States<br/>in terms of the volume of reservoir sediment potentially available for downstream transport<br/>(approximately 3 million m3; another 2 million m3 are being mechanically removed); (2) the<br/>dam is the downstream end of the largest Superfund site in the United States, the Clark Fork<br/>Complex, and reservoir sediments are composed largely of contaminated mine tailings; (3) it<br/>is occurring on a regionally important river that includes designated Critical Habitat for<br/>bull trout, a federally threatened species. Systematic study of this dam removal will therefore<br/>have broader impacts on multiple levels, including for understanding the sediment and metals<br/>transport associated with a significant dam removal, for the insights it lends to upcoming<br/>planned removals of large dams, and for its broader contribution to understanding how gravel-bed<br/>rivers respond to increased sediment fluxes. Broader impacts will also derive from the project?s<br/>interdisciplinary nature, whereby analyses of geomorphic processes, geochemistry, hydrology,<br/>and fish response will be combined to understand downstream effects of dam removal.<br/>This project will help a new faculty member build a research program in fluvial geomorphic<br/>processes and will directly support one graduate and one undergraduate student. The project<br/>will also foster ongoing collaboration efforts between University of Montana and Salish-Kootenai<br/>College, a tribal college in Pablo, MT, whose students will assist field data collection and<br/>analysis under the guidance of the PI. Further, data collection and analysis related to Milltown<br/>Dam removal will be incorporated into graduate and undergraduate geomorphology and geochemistry<br/>courses, an integration of teaching and research that will be facilitated by the project?s<br/>close proximity to the University of Montana.
